repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Small Coconut Farms
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            satisfactory, and sustainability is likely, with significant
            impacts on institutional development. Nonetheless, the
            lessons suggest that: 1) although a long-term coconut
            development program has been prepared, there is still lack
            of consensus on the precise elements for the strategy of
            this program. Issues include the competition faced by
            coconut oil from substitutes in export markets, the
            agronomic constraint of shading, and a "holistic"
            approach in the preference to keep coconut as a secondary
            crop, or to diversify out of it to other profitable crops,
            or uses; 2) the private sector needs to be actively pursued,
            for experience shows that the private sector's contract
            services are more reliable, than attempting to establish
            separate public sector facilities; 3) innovative financing
            mechanisms need to be addressed, particularly, alternative
            cost-sharing arrangements should evolve to finance a
            long-term replanting program; 4) likewise, mechanisms to
            reduce planting costs should be explored, to help develop a
            market for coconut hybrid seedlings for replanting purposes.
            Experience suggests that hybrids may outperform tall
            coconuts, making those worth producing; and, 5) project
            delays undermined its benefits, thus project readiness at
            entry is critical for a timely implementation, which should
            include clear monitoring and evaluation practices.

repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Small Coconut Farms
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The need for a long term development
            program for the coconut sector has been recognized for many
            years.  This project will constitute the first phase of a
            long term small coconut farms development program, which,
            over the next twenty years, will result in the replanting of
            some 743,000 ha of senile coconuts and the rehabilitation of
            418,000 ha of low bearing palms.  Project objectives are to
            : a) launch a long term program of coconut replanting and
            productivity improvement; b) increase the incomes of coconut
            smallholders by improving coconut yields and copra quality;
            and c) boost foreign exchange earnings by ensuring an
            increasing and reliable supply of higher quality copra for
            processing and export.  Project components include : 1)
            establishment of seedgardens, nurseries and other
            infrastructure sufficient to sustain a long term program of
            replanting 50,000 ha of senile palms per annum; 2) replant
            25,000 ha and support intercropping during the first 3 years
            of replanting; 3) rehabilitate 348,000 ha of middle aged
            palms and support the development of 50,000 ha of immature
            palms; 4) support a pilot copra quality improvement program;
            and 5) provide for the institutional strengthening of the
            Philippines Coconut Authority (PCA).

            Development Project
